If a finite system of $r$ congruences $\{ a_i\pmod{n_i} : 1\leq i\leq r\}$ (the $n_i$ are not necessarily distinct) covers $2^r$ consecutive integers then it covers all integers.



This is best possible as the system $2^{i-1}\pmod{2^i}$ shows. This was proved indepedently by Selfridge and Crittenden and Vanden Eynden \cite{CrVE70}.




References


[CrVE70] Crittenden, R. B. and Vanden Eynden, C. L., Any $n$ arithmetic progressions covering the first $2^n$ integers cover all integers. Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. (1970), 475-481.
